results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 01. Human Origins
results.creator_credit: Taylor Downing, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode looks at the origins of mankind; where we come from, and how we differ from other forms of life on earth. It traces our descent from apes in trees, to land apes who stood erect, to our large brain development 500,000 years ago. Since that time no brain development has occurred, only changes in appearance to suit the different climates that existed after the ice-age. 10,000 years ago humans reached a social and cultural level which put them far above other animal life. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: Rock-a-bye baby
results.creator_credit: L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World We Live In”.
Examines some of the techniques psychologists use to assess mothering practices with young infants. Stresses the importance of touch and movement in young children. Examples of monkeys in isolation, children in orphanages, and premature infants are used to show the effects of various maternal deprivations. Narrated by Dan Ingram. NB: CONTAINS SOME DISTURBING IMAGES WITH MONKEYS.

results.title: The Dam builders: beavers and man
results.creator_credit: L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Broadcast
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World We Live In”.
A comparison of the ecological changes brought about by the dam building activities of two species of mammals - humans and the beaver. It shows that all life is interdependent and points out how humans are damaging the ecological balance of nature whereas the beaver, although bringing change to its area, is not. Shows beavers in north America and engineers in Africa. Narrated by Joseph Julian.

results.title: The Child watchers
results.creator_credit: Jean Oser, L. Richard Ellison, National Educational Television and Time-Life Broadcast
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World We Live In”.
The reflexes of a newborn baby are the basis for early learning, this is shown to be more extensive than was once thought. Experiments by developmental psychologists such as Piaget and Brunner are demonstrated with children up to the age of 6. Based on the book “The Mind” by John Rowan Wilson - a volume in the Life Science Library. Narrated by Luis Van Rooten. Suggested audience: senior secondary, tertiary, general.

results.title: The World of work
results.brief_description: A series of short films which look at different aspects of work in Australia. Of particular interest to adolescents. Teacher’s notes accompany the videos.

group_works.title: TV news: behind the scenes
group_works.creator_credit: Randolph Hobler, Michael Livesey, John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: Microchips rule OK
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World of work”.
A short and impressionistic film which poses the question are computers a good or bad thing for the workforce? Includes interviews with unemployed youth, workers and archival footage of the introduction of computers into the workplace. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

group_siblings.title: TV news: behind the scenes
group_siblings.creator_credit: Randolph Hobler, Michael Livesey, John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films

results.title: TV news: behind the scenes
results.creator_credit: Randolph Hobler, Michael Livesey, John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World of work”.
Follows one day’s preparation of an evening TV news broadcast at a major New York studio, showing how stories are assigned and reported, with examples of on the spot coverage. Concentrates on the editorial and technical teamwork involved in the selection and final preparation of news stories to be presented on air, with special emphasis on the contributions of key members of the newsroom staff. Narrated by John Barnes.

results.title: The World of Peter Rabbit and friends
results.creator_credit: John Coates, Frederick Warne and Company and TVC London
results.brief_description: The delightful drawings and stories of Beatrix Potter are stunningly recreated in this excellent series. From the mischievious Peter Rabbit and his near fatal encounter with Mr. McGregor, to Jemima Puddle-duck and her naive trust in the Fox, these stories will entertain and stimulate young minds.

results.creator_credit_for_label: John Coates, Frederick Warne and Company and TVC London

results.title: The Tale of Peter Rabbit and Benjamin Bunny
results.creator_credit: Dennis Abey, Geoff Dunbar, Ginger Gibbons and Grand Slamm Partnership
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World of Peter Rabbit and friends”.
Beatrix Potter’s beautifully illustrated books have long been a favourite with children. Her stories of the mischievous cousins, Peter Rabbit and Benjamin Bunny, come to life on the screen in this delightful animated adaptation. The video includes a live-action introduction dramatising Beatrix Potter and the animals that inspired her books.
